channel.title: Looking to getting into making music
channel.description:
So, I'm not sure if this is the right place to post this, but anywho..
I love listening to music that have a really good beat, which has motivated me to start making beats of my own. One problem; how and with what?
So the thing I'm asking you guys is that: 1. Which programmes are good for this type of thing? 2. Any tips?
Thanks :D

item.title: Looking to getting into making music
item.dc:creator: @bib bib
item.description:
@bib wrote:

You might want to try the tracker route instead of using FL. Famitracker (NES/famicom music + some extra channels), deflemask (Gameboy, NES, Genesis, C64 and some others), and renoise are all excellent.

Read full topic
item.source: Looking to getting into making music

item.title: Looking to getting into making music
item.dc:creator: @hely hely
item.description:
@hely wrote:

noproblems, if you need any help with fl studio feel free to pm me ur skype or something

Read full topic
item.source: Looking to getting into making music

item.title: Looking to getting into making music
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“hely, post:3, topic:549880”]It doesn’t really matter what DAW you uses, you just got to play around with it. It is kinda compareable to an IDE. If you are running OSX I highly suggest u use logic pro x since it’s extremely easy to use and delivers high and professional quality and doesn’t require much knowledge of daw’s or VST plugins.

If you’re on windows I suggest u get FL studio, mainly because a ton of people use it and there are a lot of tutorial for it so it’s great to start with fl studio and maybe move on to ableton in a later stage.[/quote]
Even if it is a late reply, I appreciate it a lot. Going to using FL studio and hopefully come up with some good tracks. Thanks

Read full topic
item.source: Looking to getting into making music

item.title: Looking to getting into making music
item.dc:creator: @hely hely
item.description:
@hely wrote:

It doesn’t really matter what DAW you uses, you just got to play around with it. It is kinda compareable to an IDE. If you are running OSX I highly suggest u use logic pro x since it’s extremely easy to use and delivers high and professional quality and doesn’t require much knowledge of daw’s or VST plugins.

If you’re on windows I suggest u get FL studio, mainly because a ton of people use it and there are a lot of tutorial for it so it’s great to start with fl studio and maybe move on to ableton in a later stage.

Read full topic
item.source: Looking to getting into making music

item.title: Looking to getting into making music
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

It’s a bit late to reply but I use garageband and I sent one to my friend and he said it sounded professional (he did not know it was made with garageband until after he said that).

Be warned that to get realistic sounding instruments in garageband will take some time and fiddling with modifiers.

Read full topic
